channel.title: Bacon Girls Who Code
channel.description: Building the pipeline of future engineers, one kid at a time

item.title: 2019-2020 Club Information
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
Girls Who Code is on a mission to close the gender gap in technology and to change the image of what a programmer looks like and does.

Our Program

3rd thru 5th Graders

GWC is part of Bacon's after school enrichment program, providing an additional hour of activities in the areas of technology, music, physical fitness, and foreign languages.

Club meetings every Monday

Meetings are every Monday from 2:33 until 3:33. We meet in the gym and then move to Room 221.

Multi-modal curriculum

We use a mix of reading assignments, Socratic discussion, role-playing activities, and proven coding learning tools like Scratch and Swift Playgrounds.

About Us

Michele and Steve have lived in Colorado for 12 years and Fort Collins for two, and their kids have attended Bacon since 2018.

We're starting with GWC because we strongly support their goal of closing the gender gap in technology. But don't be surprised if the Bacon Coding Club morphs and grows over the next few years.

One of our goals is to develop a coding club program that we can leave behind when our kids move to middle school. If you have boys or girls in K-2nd, I'm looking at you ...

Want to help?

Latest Blog Post: Weekly Lesson Plans

Resources for kids and parents

Contact

Session 3 slots have been filled, but please get in touch if youâ€™d still like more info:

item.title: Curriculum
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded: Our curriculum is designed for students with a wide range of computer science experience. We have activities for girls with zero computer science experience all the way up to activities that introduce college-level concepts. The broad set of soft and hard skills we teach are:

item.title: Lessons
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
Lesson 1 â€” Sept 9: Ice breaker, introductions, how computers think. Activity: Robots and Programmers.

Lesson 2 â€” Sept 16: How programmers and computers think, introduction to Scratch

Lesson 3 â€” Sept 23: A little history, and then getting into Scratch, the Scratch sandbox, code blocks, making your Sprite talk and move.

gwc-lesson-3Download
getting-started-with-scratchDownload

Lesson 4 â€” Sept 30: Variables, Loops, and Sequencing

In-Club Reading (passage from L2C/CtW)Download
Sequencing ExerciseDownload

Lesson 5 â€” Oct 7: Algorithms and PseudoCode

  • The Elements of PseudoCode at the Viking School
  • How to Explain Algorithms
  • Printing "Hello, World" in different programming languages

Lesson 6 â€” Oct 14: Functions

â€¢ Learn to Code, Chapter 3Download

â€¢ Scratch project: Using pens to track motion

â€¢ Using Pens tutorialDownload

â€¢ Scratch project: Knock-Knock Jokes

â€¢ Knock-Knock Jokes tutorialDownload

Two week break until the next class (October 28)

Lesson 7 â€” Oct 28:

â€¢ Icebreaker and introductions for new club members

â€¢ Binary numbers

  1. Binary Bracelets
  2. How to tie off your bracelet or necklace
3. Binary bracelet worksheetDownload

Lesson 8 â€” Nov 4:

  • Review: Functions
Functions:Download
  • Design - Build - Test Cycle
D-B-T:Download
  • Scratch: Knock-Knock Joke

Nov 11th: No school

Lesson 9 â€” Nov 18:

  • Guest speaker from the CSU IT Department
  • Creating an animated holiday card in Scratch (brainstorming, designing, wire framing)
  • Scratch How-To cards
  • Debugging quiz:
debugging-quizDownload

Lesson 10 â€” Nov 25: Robotics Round-Robin (Canceled, snow day)

Lesson 11 â€” Dec 2: Circuits with guest speaker Lisa Yunker

  • Motherboards, chipsets, circuits, and hands-on time with Snapino circuit boards.
  • Thanks so much to Lisa and HP for putting this together!

Lesson 12 â€” Dec 9: End of the Year Wrap-Up

  • Circuits, electricity, and how computers think, with special guest speaker Janelle Mainz.
  • Hour of Code Dance Party!
  • Lesson Plan for the HoC Dance Party

Lesson 13 â€” Jan 13: Maker Day with Kano

Yep, we build a computer.

Lesson 14 â€” Jan 27: Intro to Sphero

Thanks to a generous donation from someone at Sphero, we have almost a dozen programmable robots to work with for the rest of the semester.

  • Sphero Edu App
  • Getting started

Lesson 15 â€” Feb 3rd: More hands-on with Sphero and the Sphero.edu app

  • Program #1: Getting Started
  • Program #2: Baby Steps

Lesson 16 â€” Feb 10: Writing functions in block coding (and navigating an obstacle course with Sphero)

  • Hour of Code: Functions and Sequences Activity
  • HoC Functions linked program

Feb 17: No club meeting for Presidents Day. Practice your Scratch at home with your Projects Workbook

Lesson 17 â€” Feb 24:

More block programming with Sphero: Coding with Tynker

tynker-and-ollieDownload

Coding-at-Home Lessons: The following lessons were provided after Spring Break when we were in stay-at-home mode.

Lesson 18 â€” Back to Basics: Stay Positive Binary Bracelets. This is a recap of one of our first club meetings, but with a new and improved hand-out. Check out the PDF download:

gwc-at-home-binary-bracelets-activityDownload

Lesson 19 â€” Coding and Art

  • Music +Art + Coding with Scratch
  • DJ Mixer using Scratch and CS First

Lesson 20 â€” April 20: Conditionals Using Scratch

Scratch Conditionals TutorialDownload

Lesson 21 â€” An overview of coding-at-home resources

  • Your HQ.GirlsWhoCode account
  • Hour of Code

Lesson 22 â€” More coding-at-home resources

  • The new Girls Who Code Coding-at-Home page
  • Scratch
  • Lynda's Scratch course
  • Scratch Jr
  • Hour of Code
  • Brain POP
  • Swift Playgrounds
  • Grasshopper
  • Minecraft

Lesson 23 â€” Getting Started with Scratch

  • A refresher for the club kids, and an intro for the new kids

Lesson 24â€” Homeschooling 101

  • Resources for all subjects while we are learning from home

Lesson 25 â€” The PSD Futures Lab Design Challenges

  • Challenge #1: Design your ultimate workstation for learning at home
  • Challenge #2: Design a paper airplane that will fly at least 10 feet, using the suggested ideation concepts for idea generation

Lesson 26 â€” GWC Coding at Home: Share Your Skills

  • Learn how to use HTML and CSS to build a tutorial that teaches someone how to do something like how to make a TikTok, how to draw a cat, how to make your favorite cookies (our project was making homemade granola), how to land a perfect water bottle flip â€“ no skill is too small!

item.title: Mission Statement
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
Girls Who Code is on a mission to close the gender gap in technology and to change the image of what a programmer looks like and does.

Weâ€™re building the largest pipeline of future
female engineers in the United States.

Computing is where the jobs are â€” and where they will be in the future, but fewer than 1 in 5 computer science graduates are women.

In 1995, 37% of computer scientists were women. Today, itâ€™s only 24%. If we do nothing, in ten years the number of women in computing will decrease to just 22%.

While girlsâ€™ participation in computer science ebbs over time, the biggest drop off happens between the ages of 13-17.

Our alumni who have already declared their majors are choosing to major in CS, or related fields, at a rateÂ 15 times the national average.

item.title: How to Sign a Student Up for Girls Who Code HQ
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters

item.title: Letter from the CEO: Women in Tech 2019
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
The follow was sent out to the GWC community this morning by Reshma Saujani, the founder of Girls Who Code.

Girls Who Code Community,

Earlier this year, we did a survey of 1,000 of our college-aged alumni, hoping to learn more about their experiences applying for internships in tech. Overall, half of the respondents - most under the age of 20 - reported having a negative experience or knowing a woman who has. 

Today, WIRED published an article with the results of our survey detailing our girls' experiences and the challenges they and other young women may face at this critical point in the pipeline. We have also, simultaneously, released a report with the results of our survey on our website. And, a group of our college-aged alumni - with support from our team - are leading a change.org petition calling for more equitable hiring practices â€“ sign your name in support. 

I hope that youâ€™ll join me, and sign the petition [SIGN HERE] that our girls put together. If youâ€™d like to share the story on social media, please retweet our tweet. 

Tech has solved some of the worldâ€™s biggest challenges â€” but it hasnâ€™t cracked the one closest to home: toxic, sexist workplace culture. Our 30,000+ GWC college-aged alumni (and ALL women) deserve better. Theyâ€™re brilliant, theyâ€™re qualified, and theyâ€™re going to change the world one day. At Girls Who Code, weâ€™re committed to making sure that no one gets in their way. And weâ€™re so glad that we can count on allies like you for support.

Thank you,

Reshma

item.title: Volunteers, facilitators, and guest speakers
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
We're still two weeks out but we've already had a handful of info requests about pitching in and helping out.

Because this club takes place during the enrichment hour, you do not need a PSD-approved volunteer application to get to the club space. Just stop at the office, tell them why you're there, and wait for the bell to ring. (However, if you do want to get volunteer credit, the volunteer registration process is quick and painless. The district does a great job with applications, and you get through in a couple of days. Just check out the PSD Volunteer page.)

The second part is being a Girls Who Code approved facilitator. This part is totally optional. The club needs one facilitator to exist, and we have two, so we're covered. If you want to sit in on the class, you're cool. If you want to lead a class, you're also cool, as long as one of the other facilitators is also there. Same goes for guest speakers. However, you might want to submit a formal facilitator application, for a couple of other reasons. If your business rewards volunteer time, it might help to have an official document recognizing you as a GWC facilitator. And another nice thing about being an official facilitator is that it gets you more resources to help your kiddo than the basic student HQ.GirlsWhoCode.com profile. You'll get all of the teacher resources, extra tutorials, and a deeper look at the curriculum.

To apply, go to:

https://girlswhocode.com/clubsapply

Please make sure to select "I've been invited to facilitate an approved 2019-20 Club, and I have the Club Code." and enter the Club CodeÂ CO14754. Once you have completed the application and have been approved, you'll have access to the 2019-20 curriculum and other resources to start the Club onÂ HQ.

Speaking of guest speakers ... We could definitely use some help recruiting a few. If you or anyone you know would like to talk to a handful of enthusiastic 3rd-5th graders about your/their experience as a woman in tech, please drop us a line. Ideally they would be available to talk live between 2:30 and 3:30 at Bacon, but we could probably Skype or FaceTime it as well.

Thanks for reading and for any help you can provide to make this first year a successful one.

item.title: The Tech Gender Gap is Solvable
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
From the Rockefeller Foundation: Solvable

Listen here to Jacob Weisberg talk to MariÃ©me Jamme about teaching a million disadvantaged girls to code.

MariÃ©me Jamme is the founder of IAMTHECODE, the first African-led global movement aiming at mobilizing governments, businesses, philanthropic foundations and investors to support marginalized girls and young women to have access to STEAMD (Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts, Mathematics, and Design) education. Their goal is to empower 1 million young women and girls to become coders by 2030.

item.title: Our first club meeting is in the books
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
Quick thoughts on the first week:

  • The 5th graders were all at Eco-Week, so it will be interesting to see if there are any changes when the older kids show up as the new kids and the 3rd and 4th graders will be the seasoned veterans with an entire extra week under their belts.
  • These 5th graders are a third of the class, so we will do intros, norms, expectations all over again next week.
  • What an interesting collection of kids. A couple really had no idea what to expect, and a couple were all full-speed-ahead, with one actually saying, "But when am I going to learn how to programâ€½" But all of them were enthusiastic, receptive, and should do well when we start pair-programming and doing other group activities.

Next week: The history of computers, Ada Lovelace, and maybe some Scratch

item.title: Setting up Scratch
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
If you want to save your projects that we start during club so that you can keep working on them at home, you'll need set up an account. Because Scratch is a free program sponsored by MIT, they've made this as simple as possible.

First, go to https://scratch.mit.edu.

On the page's upper right corner, look for "Join Scratch."

Then follow the instructions to set up your account.

A few notes for parents ... Scratch was specifically designed for kids, so they minimize the data needed for sign-up. Online projects are closely monitored to help maintain a friendly and respectful working environment. You can review MIT's policies here. And if you need to limit your child's online exposure, they have a desktop version that does not require internet access.

item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters

item.title: Apple Entrepreneur Camp completes its first year of training with its fourth cohort
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
From the Apple Newsroom:

Today marks the completion of Apple Entrepreneur Campâ€™s first year with its fourth cohort of 2019. Apple Entrepreneur Camp is specifically designed for organizations founded and led by women, and dedicated to helping entrepreneurs as they work on the next generation of cutting-edge apps. The camp offers a hands-on technology lab, one-on-one code-level guidance from Apple experts and engineers as well as mentorship, inspiration and insights from top Apple leaders. After the lab concludes, participants get ongoing support and become part of a growing community of exceptional alumni who can help create and build businesses.

item.title: Women in Tech Profile
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
Are you a teenager or middle schooler reading a book about coding? Then there's a good chance it was written by Kiki Prottsman. Kiki is the author of six best-selling books about learning to code, and as a curriculum developer at Code.org, she has been in the forefront of the fight for gender equity and social responsibility in the academic and corporate computing environments. She has worked with Disney to develop coding tutorials such as Moana's Wayfinding with Code adventure, and she is on the advisory board of Wonder Workshops Robotics, the makers of the super-popular Dash and Dot. And somehow, in her free time, she makes videos about learning to code for her YouTube channel, KikiVsIT.

You can read more about her work here.

item.title: Computer Science Education: Who Gets Ahead, Who Is Left Behind?
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
From The Hill:

In California, the tech capital of the world, only 39 percent of its high schools offer computer science courses, and just 3 percent of Californiaâ€™s 1.9 million high school students took a computer science course in 2017. Computer science is often only offered in high-income areas with less diverse student populations. Students of color, rural students, and low-income students are much less likely to have access to these foundational courses or to be actively engaged in them. Despite significant efforts from national, state and local leaders, agencies, and organizations, these trends are similar across every state. By the end of high school, only a select few students have developed foundational computing skills and knowledge needed to pursue degrees and careers in computing-related fields.

These numbers are scary, troubling, disappointing, and depressing. But they also show an opportunity, one just sitting there waiting for a little bit of attention and a modicum of resources. This is an easy fix.

item.title: Why support Girls Who Code?
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
Because kids like Alaina don't make amazing breakthroughs like this without encouragement.

Teen girl invents simple, yet innovative way to remove blind spots in cars

item.title: Important Notice About Session 4
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
Sorry about the admin hiccup here. The after-school programs matrix recycled the Session 3 link, which made no sense in the context of Session 4, so I've had to delete and repost this note.

Here's the bottom line: Session 4 was fully booked before Session 3 had ended. That's bad news for any new kids who wanted to try out the coding program. But it's good news for 2020-2021, because we've learned a lot to build on this past year.

We tried to figure out how to run two concurrent programs for Session 4 â€” a new session for new kids starting at the beginning, and a continuation of the existing course for the kids already enrolled. But because we're doing this with volunteer facilitators and without support from full-time teachers, we just didn't feel comfortable trying to manage that.

But that is definitely an option for next year.

Speaking of next year ... We'd like to get feedback from everyone, whether your kid participated or not, so that we can start planning for the fall. There are some obvious ways we can modify the after-school coding club program, and I'm sure there are some great ideas we haven't thought of yet. If you have a couple of minutes, let us know what you'd like to see next year in the space below.

Thanks in advance!

item.title: Are coding robots with your kids' time?
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
Here are a couple of perspectives over at Mashable in an article by Sarah Lindenfeld Hall. While they are mostly talking about coding robots in particular, a lot of the arguments can be extrapolated onto the larger idea of teaching coding, period.

I think even the most enthusiastic supporters of pushing coding into the K-8 curriculum will admit that we don't have a lot of data to support our beliefs. We have moved from punch cards to the Apple IIe to block-style coding environments so quickly that we haven't been able to study the effectiveness of any one program with a lot of clarity.

And it also goes without saying that for any educational initiative, there are always unscrupulous vendors who just want to make a buck who will sell us anything under the marketing banner of ensuring our kids aren't left behind.

But I found this sentiment confusing:

â€œItâ€™s an incredibly misguided force in our culture right now, largely driven by an opportunity to make a lot of money,â€ said Jim Taylor, a psychologist and author ofÂ Raising Generation Tech: Preparing Your Children for a Media-Fueled World.Â â€œThis pressure to get your kids coding and on the tech train is based entirely on fear â€¦ Itâ€™s based on the premise that somehow coding is an essential part of [a] kid's future career path.â€

I personally don't know anyone under the impression that we are trying to anticipate, dictate, or otherwise put our thumb on the scale in determining our kids' career paths by emphasizing tech, coding, or STEM in our schools.. Let's scale back just a little bit and ask the same question about math, English comp, music, or physical education. Do we teach any of those for the sole purpose of forcing a kid's hand in picking a job? Of course not.

If Mr. Taylor had simply said, whoa, let's slow down a bit, and let's collect some data so that we can match programs with outcomes, then I wouldn't have a problem agreeing. But in my way-too-short experience here, a kid's future career path is Consideration #237 in why we're teaching coding. The problem solving skills that kids learn while coding also help them with algebra, book reports, debate club, and on the sports field. Coding as a creative endeavor can be as challenging and satisfying as painting with water colors, design in PhotoShop, or molding with clay. And I've seen peer programming practices help kids with totally different learning styles collaborate in ways that other group work activities never brought to light.

None of that, of course, is an argument for spending precious school dollars on every new gadget that hits the market. But it is a reason to continue to study the field and to see where it goes next.

item.title: The Architect of Modern Algorithms
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
An interview with one of the most influential computer scientists of all time, the inventor of data abstraction, Turing Award winner, and all around cool person, Barbara Liskov.
One advantage to being in the field so early was that great problems were sitting there. All you had to do was jump on them.
Read the entire interview here.

item.title: Business Casual interview with GWC CEO Reshma Saujani
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
Computer Science Education Week is coming up, and if you need another reason why this is such an important subject, then take 30 minutes and listen to the CEO of Girls Who Code, Reshma Saujani, as she sits down with the great team at Morning Brew to talk about why we're doing what we're doing.

There is a gender gap in tech, and that gender gap leads to worse products for everyone. We donâ€™t have to be the ones to tell you thatâ€™s a problem, but...thatâ€™s a problem. Girls Who Code CEO Reshma Saujani explains.

Listen on Apple Podcasts here.

item.title: 2019 Wrap-Up
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
We need to start by thanking Lisa Yunker and Janelle Mainz for wrapping up the semester with their amazing classes. The kids loved the hands-on activities, and we hope to incorporate more classes like that in the new year.

We closed out the semester with a coded dance party, which came from one of Code.org's most popular modules, the Hour of Code Dance Party. Because we have about a month until the next Girls Who Code session, I wanted to link to this module, since it works so well as a self-paced learning opportunity, the kind of thing you might be looking for when the kids get cabin fever over the holiday break.

The HoC Dance Party can be found in a couple of different places on the Bacon Tech website, so your kids probably already know how to get to it. You can look for the Code.org logo in the link matrix, or follow the header above that grid.

Like Scratch, Code.org tries to stay out of the data collection business, so there is very little risk that you kids will be targeted with ads if they sign up for an account. But they can run through the entire tutorial without an account. The only issue that they will have is that, without an account, they won't be able to save their work. Even that isn't a big deal. If they run the program without signing in, and they want to quit and come back later, they can skip back to whatever level they want.

On the Hour of Code Activities page, look for the Dance Party link. If you want to check it out first, there is a lesson plan under the Teacher Resources block. But since they've already seen the introduction, your kiddo should be able to go straight to the lessons without much if any outside instruction. From there, the lessons start with a quick video addressing that particular topic (characters, events, properties, initial conditions), followed by a task.

If you get stuck, there are hints along the way -- just look for the cool cat with the lightbulb.

Based on what we've done in GWC so far this year, every one should be able to get through the ten levels of the first module. And if they run into trouble, just remember, it's nothing but electrons, so they can't break anything! Just keep trying until you get it to work. There is a second module, called Keep On Dancing, that we will explore in January, but they should be able to tackle it on their own if they want to play with it over the holidays.

We hope your kids had a great time this past semester, and we're really looking forward to seeing what's ahead in 2020. Thank you so much for your support of Bacon's Girls Who Code.

Steve and Michele

item.title: Make a Gift, Change the World
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
When you invest in Girls Who Code, you give girls the tools they need to change the world. 

Just this fall, our girls at Johnson Central High School in Kentucky created an app that helps students find a buddy to eat with during their lunch period so no one has to sit alone. And you might already know about Natalia, one of our undocumented alumni, who used her coding skills on a film about immigration reform. And then thereâ€™s Anastasia, one of the youngest people to get a patent for gun safety technology that alerts police if a gun goes off near a school. 

As a member of the GWC community, we are grateful for your support of our work. I hope you will consider making a personal gift today because when you teach a girl to code, sheâ€™ll change the world

Thank you for being part of this work, and happy holidays,

Reshma 
Founder & CEO

item.title: COVID-19 Update
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
Girls Who Code's 4th quarter session was full before it was even announced. And then this particular strain of coronavirus hit, and now who knows if we'll hold another club meeting during the 2019-2020 school year. But we're driving on, running the club as an asynchronous resource and providing additional resources as we stumble upon them.

The bad news is, of course, that we're not holding weekly meetings. But the good news is that we are not constrained by classroom size any more. We can expand the club to any and every 3rd, 4th and 5th grade girl that goes to Bacon.

What does signing up for GWC get you at this point in the year? Access to the lesson plans, tutorials, and the Learn to Code and Change the World text book. There won't be anyone to facilitate the sessions, but you will get resources that might help you through the next month of homeschooling. And maybe it will be something that you'll want to check out when we're back for the 2020-2021 school year.

So, if you're interested, drop us a line below, and we'll get you an access invitation.

item.title: Getting through the next couple of weeks (months?)
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
Virtual/distance/asynchronous learning is hard enough on a good day, but our district now finds itself in the position of creating a tele-learning program on the fly. The good news is that there have never been so many resources to make this happen as there are today, and so many options are free or have become free for the next few months while we all try to figure out what's next. (In fact, I have already heard folks complaining that there are too many choices out there.)

At a minimum, we know that Bacon's Girls Who Code Club will not meet until April 20th. But there is an entire universe of things that the girls can do at home, mostly entirely self-paced (although parents are more than welcomed to play along). The secret sauce to these activities and projects is that they all look like fun screen-time breaks from their homework, so they don't even realize that they're actually learning cool stuff.

For starters, there's their GWC account at HQ.GirlsWhoCode.com. Everything here is accessible on an iPad, Chromebook, or any old PC or Mac.

Once they are logged in, the first thing they will see on the left menu is the link to a PDF version of Learn to Code and Change the World. If they want to read it straight through without the commentary or projects, then just stick to the sections that say "Chapter X, Passage Y."

The next block under the Learn to Code section is, I'm guessing, the part that the kids will have the most fun with. GWC has provided a handful of Scratch tutorials that will walk them through building their own programs.

Another resource during our extended Spring Break is the Lessons page here on our WordPress site. We've tried to document everything that we've done in our club meetings, so you will find links to other Scratch projects, the instructions to the binary necklace class, and some of the Hour of Code projects that we did in class.

Speaking of Hour of Code ... you can't go wrong with anything on Code.org's Hour of Code page. These projects are designed for non-tech teachers of all grades to jump right in and learn alongside their students, so they have a couple of features that make them perfect for homeschooling. For starters, the modules are designed to be stand-alone projects â€” you can jump right in to any of them regardless of your coding level. And they are intended for a classroom to take about an hour to finish, so if you are working solo or in pairs, they usually take about 30 minutes, so parents can easily monitor screen time.

We did the Dance Party back in December, but it's a great one to go back to as often as you want because you get a physical education break at the end of each module. And once you get to the different dance moves, there are an infinite number of permutations that the kids can build.

Another good "getting started" project is the Moana Wayfinding project, which uses block-style programming to solve various navigation problems. Also highly recommended are the Minecraft projects. All of the projects are sortable by skill-level, so you can start at "beginner" and see how far you can go.

That should get everyone started for Week One. I'll update this on Monday with a few more resources.

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: Coding Resources While We're All in Homeschool Mode – Bacon Girls Who Code

item.title: Homeschooling 101
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
Help is on the way, they said. Almost too much help, it turns out. The tech community has really embraced the "we're all in this together" mentality, and new resources are popping up every five minutes.

This week I'm sharing a list of online learning resources that are not coding-specific. Next week's list will lean more in the tech direction, but the folks below are great for math, English, and everything in between.

In the "getting started" category, Khan Academy published this great template for planning a homeschooling day. It covers pre-K through 12th grade, with links to KA courses if you need extra work. Khan Academy Jr, of course, is a great app to have on your tablet.

Wide Open School is part template, part resource link, and 100% easy to use. Two questions: Are you a parent or teacher? And what grade are you looking for? Then select topics and youâ€™re off to the races.

Everyone should check out BrainPOP, if only because their free access will probably expire at the end of the school year. BrainPOP normally runs $30/month, but they are currently providing their program free of charge while schools are out of session.

What can you do with BrainPOP? Pretty much everything.

I'm sure everyone has seen the "DK" logo on a book that you either own or that your kiddo checked out from the library. Dorling Kindersly has been publishing quality books forever, from early reader board books to collaborations with the Royal Geographic Society. You can't really say that they focus on kids' books, because they offer great stuff for grownups, but they do take kids very seriously, and in that spirit they run a website called DKFindOut, which is basically a kid-friendly version of Wikipedia. It's a great site to bookmark for kids' research and homework help.

Speaking of books ... if you need to save your own voice and want to hear Oprah Winfrey, Chris Pine, Betty White, or Rita Moreno read to your kids, check out this list at We Are Teachers, most of which redirect to Storyline Online.

And Audible has also provided a free collection of audio books aimed at K-12 students. â€œFor as long as schools are closed, weâ€™re open. Starting today, kids everywhere can instantly stream an incredible collection of stories, including titles across six different languages, that will help them continue dreaming, learning, and just being kids.â€ Go to the special Stories page at Audible to see what is available.

Time for Kids is also getting into the act, offering a free subscription for the rest of the school year. You'll get the grade-specific magazine, lesson plans, quizzes and worksheets, and access to their entire digital library.

Have your kids already read the Harry Potter series? Yes or no, Wizarding World (Pottermore 2.0 with a lot of Scholastic input) is a great way to start out or to revisit the books, with special guests reading a new chapter each week, and writing prompts, reading comprehension quizzes, and arts and crafts projects to go along with it.

And just out this week (May 26), JK Rowling's latest book, The Ickabog, is being release free online, one chapter at a time. Readers are encouraged to submit concept art to go along with each chapter, which might make the final published version later this year.

Humans cannot live on math and English alone, so we have to throw a little art in there. My kids are totally into Lunch Doodles with Mo Willems, a daily offering from the Kennedy Center Artist-in-Residence. About thirty minutes long, Mo leads them through some "how to sketch" classes.

Apple also has a ton of goodness in their â€œEveryone Can Createâ€ series, which starts with a simple monthâ€™s worth of projects and builds up into a complete standards-aligned curriculum covering photography, video production, drawing, and music.

All of the above are sites that I have personally checked out. But there are a ton more on my list to visit over the next couple of weeks. Just from trusted names, the list includes:

  • The kids zone at the San Diego Zoo
  • Daily projects from Scholastic Learn at Home
  • Virtual tours of Yellowstone and other national parks
  • Visit Mars courtesy of the Curiosity Rover
  • The Weird But True! page at National Geographic Kids
  • A video collection that's way safer than YouTube is the PBS Learning Media collection
  • The Jet Propulsion Lab at NASA.gov has cool hands-on projects for all ages, like this home-made straw-rocket.

That's probably enough for Week One. We'll get tech-y next week and talk about coding resources to keep us going while GWC clubs are on hold.

item.title: Getting started with Scratch
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
Scratch is an amazing learning and development environment, but it has one problem: getting started. Like any ecosystem in which users are encouraged to share their work, there are thousands of great examples of easy to follow projects, but there are millions of not-so-great examples, and it's hard to tell which is which until you've messed around under the hood for a while.

That's where the public library comes in. If you have a Poudre River Library card, you're in luck.

Before you click the link, however, the have to create an account with Lynda.com through your Poudre River Public Library account.

Starting at the beginning ...

1) Log into your PRL account: https://www.poudrelibraries.org/

2) Click the green â€œResearchâ€ tab and scroll down to Lynda.

3) Find your library card number. Youâ€™ll need it to create a Lynda account.

(This step might be a little annoying. Your card number is in â€œMy Accountâ€ in the library app, but not on the website. So you might need to find your physical library card.)

4) Create a Lynda account.

5) Search for â€œScratchâ€ or go to https://www.lynda.com/Scratch-tutorials/First-Look-Scratch-3-0/2804663-2.html?org=poudrelibraries.org

Lynda also has courses on Raspberry Pi, Arduino circuits, Swift Playgrounds, and other fun stuff, so itâ€™s a great resource, and youâ€™re saving $30/month by having a library card.

item.title: Coding Resources While We're All in Homeschool Mode
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
(If you haven't seen the list of kitchen sink resources, check out last week's post here.)

When it rains, it pours. I thought I'd have trouble finding good resources to help keep the kids busy over the next four or more weeks. But it seems like everyone wants to pitch in, and now the problem is sorting our way through the deluge of offerings.

And, of course, we have to start with Girls Who Code. For starters, everyone still has access to all of the content that we've been using since September.

Additionally, GWC will put out weekly projects on their new platform, Girls Who Code at Home. These will feature projects that you can do on a tablet or computer, and also unplugged activities (such as this week's binary bracelets). You can bookmark the GWC at Home site, or just look at your kid's HQ.GirlsWhoCode.com account and I'll post them to the Announcements page.

(I can't even keep up with my own updates. Since I started typing, GWC has updated their resources page twice. And there is now a dedicated Girls Who Code at Home tab in your kid's hq.girlswho.code page.)

Scratch is one of the best places to send your kid to mess around for a while, and they have updated their "Ideas" page to make it more user-friendly for parents. If you're not familiar with block-style programming, there are some great getting-started tips to help navigate the system.

There's a quick tutorial over at Lynda.com that will get you up and running in 40 minutes, and the tutorials at GWC are also a great place to start.

Another way to get started with Scratch is with Scratch Jr, a free app available on both Apple and Android platforms. Scratch Jr is aimed at K-3rd graders, but for older kids it still makes a great intro to block programming, and it has easy-to-follow tutorials so everyone can figure it out on their own. And they have partnered with PBS Kids to provide lots of extra activities and projects for hours of self-paced fun.

The Hour of Code at Code.org has always been one of the best one-stop-shops for self-contained coding lessons, lessons broken down into terms that parents and kids can follow together with little or no prior coding experience, and lessons that will work on whatever device you have on hand without downloading or signing up for anything. Hard to improve on this ecosystem, but somehow they have, with their new Learning at Home page. There you will find short 3-5 minute tutorial videos, links to their best getting-started projects, and their weekly Zoom-based Code Break live tutorial.

Last week, I mentioned BrainPOP's current offer for unlimited access as long as schools are out. I would recommend starting on the BrainPOP Jr side and checking out their computer science modules, simply because this is the first week of the new normal and we're all still getting a feel for the homeschooling workflow. The courses on the main BrainPOP side are all great, but they are fully developed courses, not just snippets or mini-projects.

There are a million coding apps on the Apple and Google app stores, and 99% of them get mixed reviews. Two tried and true apps are Swift Playgrounds and Grasshopper. Swift Playgrounds was iOS-only for a long time but recently came over to the Mac, and Grasshopper works both in the browser or in apps on both Apple and Google platforms.

One more thing to mention ... the always-popular Minecraft platform has added a dozen free modules to a special Education section of their marketplace, available now through June.

Educators around the world are doing everything they can to provide digital lessons for the half a billion students who are out of school due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This is not an easy task and we want to do our part to help keep young minds sharp and stimulated. 

Sofia Dankis, Minecraft Marketplace

I'm sure that's enough for now. I am going to keep updating this page as the school year goes on, so keep checking back here if you need more ideas. And let me know if you have any questions about any of these platforms. Happy coding!

item.title: Using Conditionals in Scratch
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
This is one of the foundation lessons that everyone using Scratch needs. Conditionals are what gives your code the power to react and respond. If something happens (in your game, or in the real world through a sensor or user input), then a certain response is triggered. And you can learn all about them in a 30 minute exercise in your HQ.GirlsWhoCode account.

You can download the lesson plan in PDF format here:Download

Or, start with your Girls Who Code account, and then go to the Scratch Tutorials link on the left hand column, near the bottom.

It helps if you can use two screens, like a tablet next to a laptop. But if you only have one, then open two browser tabs, and switch back and forth between the GWC tutorial page and your Scratch page.

item.title: Futures Lab Design Project
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
Submissions are due April 24

A fun design project from PSDâ€™s Futures Lab: design the ideal remote learning space.

https://twitter.com/psd_futures_lab/status/1252264407742189569?s=20

What is "design thinking"? Kelly Williams, the Design Thinking lead teacher at our Futures Lab, describes it as solving complex problems in an elegant way. It is used to solve "wicked problems," or problems that are difficult to articulate because of changing parameters or different interpretations of the problem. In this case, different grade levels might have different remote learning resource requirements, and practically everyone has their own comfort level with different technology tools. So, while we are looking for the ideal solution, we also acknowledge that there isn't a one-size-fits-all answer.

Some best practices to keep in mind? One is to use iterations of solutions to further define and refine the problem. Try to understand what your customer (which, in this case, might be you) really wants by using empathic design, a user-centric design concept that focuses on understanding the customer's problem as the starting point instead of just laundry-listing myriad solutions.

How would you design your ideal at-home learning space? What is most important to you in designing the perfect stay-at-home work station? Try to think about as many variables as you can: technology, desktop space for writing and brainstorming, lighting, the view, and anything else that you think would make a cozy and productive working environment.

Take a crack at it if you have some free time, and share your solution using #fldesignchallenge

item.title: Futures Lab Design Challenge
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
Here is our first stab at the problem, developed by Hope(9) and Nevada(7) from Bacon Elementary. And Iâ€™ll admit, we went with the RDEFC* approach. This really would have been a fun project to sit down and do a requirements analysis, needs assessment, brainstorming, and then iterate through solution sets. But the rigors of home schooling just didnâ€™t allow it this week.

*RDEFC: Rough Draft equals Final Copy

We did, however, identify a few critical requirements.

  • Dual work stations, so both sisters can work together, and occasionally one sister can take over the whole table for crafty projects, doodling space, or comparing screens or printed documents side-by-side.
  • A separate reading zone

  • Bright colors to keep you alert and awake.
  • Natural views out the window, stimulation without distraction

  • Intuitive work zones: a desk for most online assignments, a reading space, and a play zone to get up and move around.
  • Open extra-wide door to the space so mom and dad can peek in.
  • The great outdoors are just on the other side of the patio door.
  • A bulletin board for visual focus on the dayâ€™s activities

We can't wait to see the other design ideas from the rest of the PSD family!

item.title: GWC Code at Home
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
Have you been trying any of the weekly Coding at Home activities? I'll admit, stay-at-home schooling has taken up a way bigger chunk of the day that we had expected when we started this new normal thing. This weekend we made a point of trying one of the longer projects, and I think it's one that everyone can have some fun with.

Girls Who Code has made these projects available for everyone, so you don't even need to log into your HQ.GirlsWhoCode account. Start out at the Coding at Home page, and scroll down until you see this:

During uncertain times, itâ€™s important to take a break to focus on and share something that brings you joy! Learn how to use HTML and CSS to build a tutorial that teaches someone how to do something like how to make a TikTok, how to draw a cat, how to make your favorite cookies (our project was making homemade granola), how to land a perfect water bottle flip - no skill is too small! 

Here's a run-down of the project:

  • Brainstorm you project. Think of a skill that you want to share, and how you want to explain it. Maybe it's just a list, maybe you need lots of pictures. Are there supplies needed? What kind of preparation do you need, both to explain the project and to follow the instructions?
  • Open a project in Glitch. Take a few minutes to read their getting started page. Then open a "new project," select "Hello, Webpage," and check out the README.md file. Glitch is a powerful tool for collaborative app development, but all you really need to know right now is that it lets you live-preview your work as you code. As you add HTML elements, they just show up in a preview window.
  • Intro to HTML. Just follow the steps in the GWC tutorial. Keep it simple. Play around by copy/pasting some text in the existing HTML tags, then changing the tags
  • Intro to CSS. Again, keep it simple. For a starter project, just play around with changing colors and maybe fonts. The project page shows links to W3Schools and Mozilla, but for this week I'd recommend just sticking with the examples on the GWC tutorial.

Here's what we built this weekend: a recipe page for our award-winning homemade granola.

Like I just said, we kept it simple ... very simple. On the HTML side, it's just paragraphs and unordered lists, and the CSS only changes the background and font colors. The plan is to continue styling it over the next few weeks, add pictures to demonstrate the steps, and then move on to learning about page layouts.

If you want to give it a shot but need help getting started, then give us a shout on Teams. Look up Hope in the directory and we can go over some common stumbling blocks.

And, hey, if you don't have time to try this yourself ... well, then just enjoy the granola!

item.title: Links for the week of May 4
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
Lots going on this week ..

Our kids continue to work on their Coding at Home projects, like the Week 2 Share Your Skills activity. This one is especially cool because they set up the page during the first session, over maybe half an hour or so, and then they can revisit once a week indefinitely to tweak, improve, and experiment. For instance, one girl built this recipe page during the first session, nothing more than a couple of paragraphs and a picture. The next week, she turned the ingredients into a list. During another session, she played with the styling to see how using different color pickers work. We can use this simplest of projects for the rest of the summer, taking it in a different direction each week.

And did I mention ... it's Scratch Month! A new project every Monday. And who doesn't like Mondays?!?!

Did you know you can share a project like your Share Your Skills webpage using your google drive? Well, now you do.

In non-coding news ...

Adobe has been putting out some cool coloring pages for quiet time.

The American history program that brings the musical Hamilton into our schools is now available for at-home learning.

item.title: Futures Lab Design Challenge #2
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
We have another great one this week:

How might we design a paper airplane that can fly at least 10 feet?

One technique to do this would be to just try the first thing that comes to mind ... but here's what typically happens when we solve problems that way. First, we tend to do it the same way we did it most recently, and you know what Grace Hopper said about that. Second, the direction of the entire project becomes dictated by the very first step, and if that first step is sub-optimal ...

Instead, let's try this focusing on "ideation." Ideation focuses on idea generation, not idea evaluation.

â€”> Generate and explore a wide range of solutions

â€”> At first, quantity and diversity are more important than quality

Two techniques to try:

  1. Braindump: put down as many ideas as possible, using bullets or pictures
  2. Worldâ€™s worst idea: worst ideas sometimes unlock potential for great innovation

Pick one or both techniques, take pictures of your sketches or video yourself trying them out, and post them to our HQ.GirlsWhoCode announcements page.

Sketch-pad for Challenge #2Download

Â #fldesignchallenge #psdtogether #futureslab

And how did they do? Check out their work here.

item.title: #FLDesignChallenge for May 8
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
Your mission: How might we design a paper airplane that will fly at least 10 feet?

For the project parameters, see this post.

Two of our girls took on this week's challenge. They both produced two ideas, using the brain dump and world's worst ideas techniques. Then we took them to the porch and tested them out.

Contestant #1

Our 4th grader started with the "most folds possible but still looks somewhat like a plane" approach. We'll call this one the Brown Bomber.

The idea for the folds on the back was to accommodate landing gear and extra luggage, because no one likes to go for a ten foot glide and not have a toothbrush when they de-plane.

Her second "brain dump" idea was to double up the wings, with a secondary wing tipping up off of the main wing. Because the construction paper was a burnt red, we named it Fawkes.

For her "world's worst idea" submission, she went with the traditional wadded up ball of construction paper. We think it is going to lose points for aerodynamics, but might have a hidden advantage in the mass-to-surface area department.

This one was christened the Cannonball.

Contestant #2

Our second grader decided to split the wing span and fuselage 50-50 for her first design, thinking that she could tweak it in either direction after a few test flights. Because of it's design, she called it Half-n-Half.

The most dangerous phrase in the language is, "We've always done it this way."

Adm Grace Hopper

For her "worst idea," she went with barely-there wings, one big chassis with a tiny little fold on top. We're hoping this mostly-body design will keep it going straight, and the wings will hang in there long enough to take it ten feet. The first name that came to mind was Neville Longbottom.

The next step was to test our their work. Each plane was thrown on the back porch, somewhat sheltered from the wind. In most cases we recorded the average distance, but if the delta was greater than 5', we noted the high and low results.

How did they do?

Once again, thanks to our Futures Lab for another fun design challenge!

We have a couple of cool articles about the Minecraft:Education platform. â€¢ To address the lack of human interaction because of social distancing, they have released a new social-emotional learning content package for the Education edition. â€¢ A University of Penn student recreated his campus in Minecraft, which is helping the university think about the utility of its common spaces and how to use virtual space for community events.

DEV is usually a bit over the heads of our 3rd-5th grade kiddos, but this article about how the internet works is helpful for learners of all ages.

A Wired Magazine co-founder celebrates his 68th birthday with 68 bits of wisdom. Some of the goodies: â€¢ Being able to listen well is a superpower. â€¢ Pros are just amateurs who know how to gracefully recover from their mistakes â€¢ Friends are better than money. Almost anything money can do, friends can do better. In so many ways a friend with a boat is better than owning a boat. and â€¢ Over the long term, the future is decided by optimists. To be an optimist you donâ€™t have to ignore all the many problems we create; you just have to imagine improving our capacity to solve problems.

Did you notice that for around 30 minutes last week, most of your apps were crashing? Then half an hour later, everything was okay? Hereâ€™s what happened, and why it happens.

A thirteen-year oldâ€™s thoughts on distance learning.

National Geographic looks at ways to help keep your kids positive during this pandemic.

And last but never least ... this weekâ€™s Coding at Home activity from the folks who made all of this possible.

item.title: WWDC: Education
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
This summer Apple will hold its annual developersâ€™ conference online, which offers the potential to make it their biggest and best conference ever. WWDC has turned into a major media event, which is kind of weird because its goal is not to be a major marketing platform. WWDC is all about how the stuff under the hood works.

Developer Becky Hansmeyer (Snapthread, Nebraska93, and Refining Fire) shared her thoughts on what sheâ€™d like to see this year. If youâ€™re using SwiftUI, check it out. And from the perspective of our kidsâ€™ coding club, Iâ€™d like to chime in with one thought: education.

Like I said, WWDC is a conference for developers, not consumers. Appleâ€™s work in education typically isnâ€™t a major part of the week-long event. Last year, I counted two events that covered education (one session on ClassKit, and one on device distribution management), along with a handful of â€œeducator get-togethersâ€ over lunch. This year, however, Apple is holding a Swift Student Challenge, which I am sure will get significant airtime during the week, and hopefully during the keynote. But there is a difference between highlighting the great things kids are doing and providing the tools for kids to learn how to do great things.

My wishlist for Apple, then, comes down to this top ten:

  1. Treat the education market as if it is a matter of economic accessibility.

Numbers 2-10 are the same thing, in different fonts.

And they all have the same sub-bullets:

  • Swift Playgrounds is still intimidating to most teachers. Getting started needs to be more intuitive.
  • Google and Microsoft have evangelists who are indoctrinating the masses on ease of use for teachers and administrators, and pushing questionable claims of increased engagement for students (because they are confusing widget fidgeting with content engagement). It doesnâ€™t matter if your end-user experience is better if you canâ€™t get through the district admin and teacher wickets.
  • The entry level iPad is a great device, but how about prepackaging it with edutech so out of the gate youâ€™re running Tynker, Sphero, Scratch, Minecraft:Education, and other apps? (If anyone still remembers the U2 forced download, that might sound like a bad idea, but thereâ€™s a huge difference between musical tastes and education platforms.)
  • Apple has to keep its margins, but currently we have a decent spread of devices and there has to be space for a much cheaper education-centric machine. Let the iPad Air and iPad Pro do their thing, but make it easier for all families to get the entry level iPad. Similarly, the MacBook line has space for a cheaper education-themed laptop.
  • Did you know that Apple has coding club packages that are (potentially) every bit as good as Code.org or Girls Who Code? If you donâ€™t, itâ€™s because the links to find it are all over the place, links to older versions havenâ€™t been taken down yet, and instead of providing a club portal that does some of the admin for you, they arenâ€™t much more than a PDF telling you how to get started and then leaving it up to you to execute. And speaking of clubs â€¦
  • Napoleon famously described how soldiers will risk their lives for a little piece of colored ribbon to wear on their uniform, and developers love their laptop stickers and backpack pins. Why is it every education company on the planet can afford to include an entire page of stickers with their machines, and Apple tells the kids in their program to go buy a sticker sheet from Staples and then print their own Swift stickers? We started our Girls Who Code club with just eight kids, but once their friends saw the t-shirts and GWC stickers on their water bottles, we had to turn kids away.

In Beckyâ€™s wish list, she included this about Mail:

I would love to see:
A complete re-design of Mail. There is no perfect e-mail client, but like, maybe Apple could try or something?

I could say the same thing about Apple and the education market. Thereâ€™s some good stuff out there. But it is no longer a priority for Apple, and it shows.

(I'm still on the fence about publishing my chromebook war stories from this year, but if I decide to, I'll link to it here.)

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: […] who helps run a Girls Who Code after-school program at Bacon Elementary School in Colorado. His wishlist stems from a desire for Apple to once again become a major player in the education […]

item.title: Ready, Set, Dub-Dub
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
WWDC is an exciting time, even if this is your first year of a 3rd-5th grade coding club and completing your first app is still a few miles down the road. The breakout sessions, labs, and work groups might be beyond what we're doing right now, but there will still be a lot of fun news and cool demos when the first virtual version of the conference kicks off.
To get into the Dub-Dub spirit, hereâ€™s a fun activity from one of my favorite tech+education gurus, the Tech Rabbi. (Heâ€™s also the author of Educated by Design, one of the books used by our Futures Lab for their Design Thinking class.)

He uses Adobe Spark Post in this tutorial, but thereâ€™s a link in the video notes to use KeyNote (or, I guess, Slides would also work.)

To get started, youâ€™re going to screenshot the Memoji you create in the iOS Message app. Youâ€™re looking for the version with the MacBook. You can use a white background, but if you want to superimpose it over the group shot at the WWDD site, youâ€™ll want to switch your iOS devise over to night mode.

After that, itâ€™s just a matter of collecting some images to use as laptop stickers (his recommendation of Clean PNG helps a lot, because you donâ€™t have to worry about backgrounds) and then shrinking them down and placing them on the MacBook. You can then screenshot your image to use wherever you need a profile pic.

And if you used a black background, then you can make a group photo by taking a screenshot of the image over at the WWDC Ready, Set, Code page.

I canâ€™t talk about WWDC without reminding everyone that this year Apple has added a Student Swift Project Challenge. Hopefully a lot of the kids in the Futures Lab will get to submit something.

And, speaking of summer student opportunities, another reminder that the Girls Who Code Summer Immersion Program is going virtual this year. Open to all 9th-11th graders, this two-week program teaches girls the computer science skills they need to make an impact in their community while preparing for a career in tech. Participants will get exposure to tech jobs, and join a supportive sisterhood of girls in tech.

item.title: Thank you so much for participating in Baconâ€™s pilot coding club
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded: Thank you so much for participating in Baconâ€™s pilot coding club this past year! We hope the kids got a lot out of it â€” we know we learned a lot working with them. Next yearâ€™s enrichment schedule will probably be a mystery right up until the last second, and then we can count on it changing numerous times after that. Iâ€™m not sure what to say about 2020-2021 at this point. But we are planning on allocating a couple of hours per week to keep the website running all summer, to keep adding new lessons or projects, and to even work one-on-one through Zoom, Jamboard, or FaceTime if you have questions. Hope would love to meet-up with your daughter to play Minecraft, and we can set up something so that you can borrow the Spheros. Thanks again for supporting Girls Who Code! item.title: Lesson Plan Ideas for June 1-4
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
Science: The Jet Propulsion Laboratory has a great set of projects, and they provide step-by-step written instructions, easy-to-follow video walk-thrus, and hand-outs to make assembly a breeze. This week we tried the Straw Rocket, which adds data collection and visualization to the mix.

Literacy: Scholastic hit a home run with their Pottermore 2.0, now called Wizarding World. Every couple of days, you get a new chapter from Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone, read by actors from the screen and stage adaptations. And with each chapter they also provide a reading comprehension quiz, writing prompts to explore the text, and arts and crafts projects. Warning for parents: one of the objectives of the website is to get you to sign up for a Harry Potter fan club membership, but it's entirely possible to get an entire summer's worth of activities out of the Harry Potter At Home section without signing up for anything.

Math: Mathigon is a powerful program for high schoolers, but the "foundations" section (6-8th grade projects) is a work in progress. Still, there are some cool visually-oriented projects for all ages, and it is well worth a little bit of work on the part of mom and dad to dig through it.

Coding and Tech: Dust off the Week 2 Coding At Home project (we did a granola recipe webpage), and refactor it using this week's project: Wireframing 101.

After reviewing some HTML and CSS, GWC walks you through planning your wireframe, how to think about structure and content, and then gives you a couple of graphic organizers to help you layout and implement your design concepts.

item.title: Lots of people way smarter than me put out interesting and
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
Lots of people way smarter than me put out interesting and thought-provoking WWDC wish lists. At the consumer end, Jason Snell and Dan Moren covered all of the bases, from Mac and iOS to [Watch](https://www.macworld.com/article/3562785/wwdc-wish list-apple-watch-and-watchos-7.html) to [HealthKit](https://sixcolors.com/post/2020/06/wwdc-wish list-healthkit-on-ipad-and-mac/) and beyond. From the indie developer vantage point, Becky Hansmeyer gave us a brilliant take on what she has seen working with SwiftUI this past year.

Hereâ€™s a different spin on the wish list: subjects that I hope podcasters cover if and when they get face-to-face time with key Apple developers and team leaders. With the conference going full virtual slash remote slash online, it remains to be seen as to whether that means more or less access for podcasters. But we know a couple of folks somewhere will score that big sit-down with a product team leader or SVP. They say that access has a price, and from my view in the cheap seats, I never have a clue as to whether certain subjects were agreed to be off the table, or if the world-class professional podcaster just didnâ€™t have his stuff together and failed to ask the obvious.

Number One seems obvious: Developer relations, the 30% tariff, and BaseCampâ€™s Hey email service. I can see everyoneâ€™s head nodding, and theyâ€™re moving on to the next subject. But wait a second ... itâ€™s not good enough to ask the first question here. You have to have prepared follow-ups for every permutation of each answer.

Thanks to the publication of Appleâ€™s official position on Hey-gate, thereâ€™s no excuse for not having a minimum of a dozen prepared questions on this matter. Youâ€™re going to ask about consumer experience as a priority, the value Apple adds to the developersâ€™ work by adding a safe and secure market-place, the definition of â€œreaderâ€ apps, and a few more predictable topics. And each question has a doubly predicable answer, so the follow-up questions write themselves. But what Iâ€™m afraid of is that weâ€™ll hear a couple of okay questions, get some boilerplate regurgitated back at us, and weâ€™ll leave it at that.

(This is where I feel the tech podcasting community always stumbles. Maybe because so many of them are tech enthusiasts first and journalists second or third. With the exception of the nationâ€™s Chief Explainer in Chief, John Siracusa, folks look at an interview as a soft skill touchy-feely get-to-know-each-other event, instead of a technical problem to be solved.)

Number Two on my podcast wish list is education. Frankly, I really cannot believe the lack of attention this subject has received. Given that most of the country has been homeschooling and remote learning for the last four months, it seems like a topic everyone would be jumping on.

(Not that there havenâ€™t been excellent ed tech discussions out there. But you have to go to ed-first podcasts to hear them. I just find it so odd that the mainstream tech podcasts seem to have no observations or opinions about their personal home schooling activities.)

Hereâ€™s the thing about education as a tech subject: even if you donâ€™t have kids and couldnâ€™t care less what platform anyone is using, education is a subject worth looking at because of its marketing value. The marketplace is dominated by a few platforms, making Appleâ€™s education services not just products, but also marketing tools.

And Apple has been flailing at this market for the better part of the last decade. The way all MP3 players became â€œiPodsâ€ and all tablets are generically called iPads, kids in American schools are calling all laptops â€œChromeBooks,â€ regardless of who made them. From my perspective as a parent and a coding club facilitator, it just looks like Apple gave up. And Iâ€™m definitely not alone here.

To be clear, I donâ€™t care who wins the ed space market share contest, as long as the kids win with the best products. But the reality is, it doesnâ€™t matter how great your products are if no one sees them.

My questions, then, would go like this:

  • What would you say are Appleâ€™s three biggest challenges in the education space?
  • As a parent, what would you like to see Apple do better in the education space?
  • In addition to the traditional classroom, Apple is falling behind in coding club student contact hours, despite having products that favorably compare with that which is actually being used. Are we okay with this?
  • What does the college market for Apple look like in ten years if kids today are growing up on ChromeBooks? What platforms will the next generation of developers use given the tools that they are learning on today?

(I could write 700-1,000 words on the first two and give a demo on the third, and Iâ€™m pretty sure none of it would match anything that anyone in Appleâ€™s marketing department would say in public.)

Lots of WWDC thoughts and predictions out there ... canâ€™t wait to see how they all shake out in 24 hours.

item.title: Post-WWDC podcast interview wish list
item.dc:creator: highplainsdrifters
item.content:encoded:
Lots of people way smarter than me put out interesting and thought-provoking WWDC wish lists. At the consumer end, Jason Snell and Dan Moren covered all of the bases, from Mac and iOS to Watch to HealthKit and beyond. From the indie developer vantage point, Becky Hansmeyer gave us a brilliant take on what she has seen working with SwiftUI this past year.

Hereâ€™s a different spin on the wish list: my post-keynote podcast wish list. And itâ€™s simple. Iâ€™d like just one person to ask about Appleâ€™s education work.

(Frankly, I really cannot believe the lack of attention this subject has received. Given that most of the country has been homeschooling and remote learning for the last four months, it seems like a topic everyone would be jumping on.

Not that there havenâ€™t been excellent ed tech discussions out there. But you have to go to ed-first podcasts to hear them. I just find it so odd that the mainstream tech podcasts seem to have no observations or opinions about their personal home schooling activities.)

Hereâ€™s the thing about education as a tech subject: even if you donâ€™t have kids and couldnâ€™t care less what platform anyone is using, education is a subject worth examining because of its breadth and reach. The global education tech market is somewhere around $7 T/year these days, so itâ€™s not chump change. And it is a powerful marketing tool for future sales. When I was a youngster, we bought our first college computer largely based on what we had used in high school. Today, kids are buying their first personal computer based on what they learned to code on in K-5.

And Apple has been flailing at this market for the better part of the last decade. The way all MP3 players became â€œiPodsâ€ and all tablets are generically called iPads, kids in American schools are calling all laptops â€œChromeBooks,â€ regardless of who made them. From my perspective as a parent and a coding club facilitator, it just looks like Apple just gave up. And Iâ€™m definitely not alone here.

To be clear, I donâ€™t care who wins the ed space market share contest, as long as the kids win with the best products. But the reality is, it doesnâ€™t matter how great your products are if no one sees them.

My questions, then, would go like this:

  • What would you say are Appleâ€™s three biggest challenges in the education space?
  • As a parent, what would you like to see Apple do better in the education space?
  • In addition to the traditional classroom, Apple is falling behind in coding club student contact hours, despite having products that favorably compare with that which is actually being used. Are we okay with this?
  • What does the college market for Apple look like in ten years if kids today are growing up on ChromeBooks? What platforms will the next generation of developers use given the tools that they are learning on today?

(I could write 700-1,000 words on the first two and give a demo on the third, and Iâ€™m pretty sure none of it would match anything that anyone in Appleâ€™s marketing department would say in public.)

Lots of WWDC thoughts and predictions out there ... canâ€™t wait to see how they all shake out in 24 hours. Maybe Apple will spend 1-2 minutes on their recent work with SchoolWork and the Device Enrollment Program. But I hope that the tech media can show a little interest in something that impacts 75 million kids in this country by asking Apple tougher questions about their programs.
